study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of spirulina supplementation on serum iron, ferritin, anemia parameters, and fecal occult blood test in adults with ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly increased serum iron and mean corpuscular volume while preventing declines in red blood cell count and hematocrit seen in the placebo group. No significant changes in fecal occult blood test outcomes were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with ulcerative colitis (n=80, 73 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different heating treatments (water bath and microwave) could improve the digestibility and structural properties of Spirulina platensis protein (SPP).
results_summary: Microwave treatment accelerated protein denaturation, increased surface hydrophobicity, and promoted protein aggregation, leading to improved in vitro digestibility and enhanced production of small molecular peptides and free amino acids.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of spirulina sauce on glycemic indices, lipid profile, oxidative stress markers, and anthropometric measurements in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Spirulina sauce did not significantly improve glycemic control but reduced triglycerides, total cholesterol, and LDL while marginally improving appetite control and oxidative stress markers. Waist circumference also decreased significantly.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients (n=40)
effective_dosage: 20 g/day spirulina sauce (containing 2 g of spirulina)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological effects and benefits of C-Phycocyanin (C-PC) from Spirulina maxima on metabolic syndrome and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study highlights Spirulina's potential as a source of bioactive molecules for treating metabolic syndrome, coronary diseases, cancer, and modulating oxidative stress, with C-PC showing antioxidant properties but lacking a specific cellular target.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spirulina (SP), alone or combined with topiramate (TPM), could protect against doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Spirulina monotherapy significantly improved cardiac markers, reduced oxidative stress and fibrosis-related growth factors, increased antioxidants, and improved histopathological features. SP showed more prominent effects than TPM, and the combination of SP and TPM had even stronger protective effects.
population_specificity: Adult Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore innovative applications of Spirulina in sustainable development, health, and industry, focusing on its environmental and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study highlighted Spirulina's roles in wastewater treatment, biofuel production, and various health applications, including drug development, wound healing, and anticancer treatments, as well as industrial uses like biopolymer production and photovoltaic technologies.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad focus on environmental, health, and industrial applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina platensis extract could provide neuroprotective effects and improve functional outcomes following a hemorrhagic event in rats.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly more viable neurons in perilesional fields 24 hours post-hemorrhage and better motor performance in the open field test at 30 days, though other neurofunctional parameters showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral effects of a cream containing 1.5% Ca-SP and 1% Spiralin® (Spirularin® VS) against molluscum contagiosum (MC) in children.
results_summary: The study found that 73.1% of children achieved complete clearance of MC lesions after treatment with Spirularin® VS, with no reported adverse reactions or irritative skin effects. The formulation appeared effective and safe for treating MC in children.
population_specificity: Children with active molluscum contagiosum lesions.
effective_dosage: 1.5% Ca-SP and 1% Spiralin® cream applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of spirulina dietary supplementation on carcass characteristics, fatty acid profile, and meat quality traits in Omani goat breeds.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation (2 g and 4 g/head daily) improved growth performance, carcass traits, fatty acid composition, and meat quality in Sahrawi goats, with some benefits also observed in Jabbali goats. The effects were more pronounced in Sahrawi goats, particularly at the 2 g dosage.
population_specificity: 36 Jabbali and Sahrawi bucks (Omani goat breeds), aged 11 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chromium (VI) adsorption capacities of different Spirulina strains and investigate the mechanisms of binding and biotransformation.
results_summary: Spirulina strains YCX2643 and CLQ1848 showed higher chromium (VI) removal efficiency (86.5% and 83.7%) compared to other strains (59.4%-66.5%). FTIR and SEM analysis suggested that cellular components with high binding affinity contributed to their superior biosorption and bioreduction capabilities.
population_specificity: Spirulina strains (microorganisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Spirulina supplementation on growth performance, blood metabolites, puberty development, and semen quality in growing Barki lambs.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation (100 ml/head/day) improved growth performance, feed efficiency, antioxidative status, and puberty development in lambs, with better semen quality and reduced oxidative stress markers compared to controls.
population_specificity: Barki male lambs (30 lambs, average weight 21.78 ± 2.56 kg, age ~16 weeks).
effective_dosage: 50 ml (SP1) and 100 ml (SP2) per lamb daily, as a water suspension (1 g Spirulina:10 ml water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina platensis (SP) could mitigate the harmful effects of florfenicol (FF) on Oreochromis niloticus and act as an effective immunostimulant.
results_summary: SP supplementation significantly improved immune responses (phagocytic activity, IL6, TNF-α) and reduced oxidative stress and tissue damage caused by FF. The combined FF+SP treatment also enhanced hematological parameters and minimized FF-induced oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Oreochromis niloticus (Nile tilapia; n=240, 40±2.5 g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if beet filter cake extract (BFCE) could serve as a low-cost alternative growth medium for commercially producing Spirulina platensis with acceptable protein content compared to the standard Zarrouk's medium.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina platensis cultivated on 75% BFCE achieved comparable dry cell weight and protein content to Zarrouk's medium, with optimized conditions yielding biomass and protein content close to the standard. The essential amino acid content was slightly higher in the optimized medium than in the standard.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory cultivation of Spirulina platensis).
effective_dosage: Not specified (batch experiments used varying BFCE concentrations, e.g., 25%, 75%, 100%).
study_duration: Not specified (batch and adaptation experiments, duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of astaxanthin microencapsulated within spirulina (ASXSP) in preventing cognitive deficits induced by LPS in female rats.
results_summary: ASXSP improved LPS-induced cognitive deficits and reduced microglia activation in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex. It also partially reversed LPS-induced gut dysbiosis, suggesting neuroprotective benefits through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and possibly prebiotic mechanisms.
population_specificity: Female rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of supercritical fluid extraction (SFE) in recovering minerals, pigments, and antioxidant compounds from spirulina, and to assess the extracts' effects on cell viability.
results_summary: SFE improved the extraction of phycocyanin, chlorophyll a, carotenoids, and certain fatty acids compared to conventional methods. It also enhanced cell viability but increased lead (Pb) extraction, indicating a need for contaminant control.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of cold atmospheric pressure plasma (CAPP) power density on microorganism inactivation and quality of Spirulina platensis slurry.
results_summary: CAPP treatment effectively inactivated microorganisms (91.31% within 2.02 min) and increased total phenolic, Chlorophyll-a, and carotenoids content while enhancing antioxidant activity and nutrient bio-accessibility. However, it reduced phycobiliproteins, protein, intracellular polysaccharide, and moisture content.
population_specificity: Spirulina platensis slurry (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina platensis supplementation could improve impaired blood biomarkers in ICU patients with COVID-19.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation led to significant improvements in hematocrit, platelet count, lymphocyte percentage, BUN, LDH, serum protein, albumin, zinc levels, and BAR, but no immunological or hormonal differences were observed.
population_specificity: Hospitalized ICU patients with COVID-19 (aged 48-66; 61.5% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of Spirulina supplementation on plasma lipid profile concentrations in randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Spirulina significantly reduced LDL-C, TC, and TG levels while increasing HDL-C levels, indicating its effectiveness in improving lipid profiles.
population_specificity: 1076 participants across 20 studies (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel 3D printing material from Spirulina platensis residues with specific rheological properties for food applications.
results_summary: The study clarified the effects of moisture content and pretreatment on rheological properties, identified key 3D printing factors (viscosity, modulus), and demonstrated successful printing under ambient conditions, promoting high-value utilization of microalgae residues.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human or animal subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of Spirulina's nutritional composition, therapeutic potential, and applications in the food industry.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina is a rich source of complete proteins, essential fatty acids, vitamins, minerals, and bioactive compounds, with potential benefits for treating diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disorders, COVID-19, neuroinflammatory conditions, and gut dysbiosis. It also highlighted its use in various food formulations, including sports supplements, bakery products, and beverages.
population_specificity: Not specified (general overview of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of cultivating Spirulina platensis in piggery wastewater for biomass production and nutrient removal.
results_summary: Spirulina platensis grew well in diluted piggery wastewater, achieving a biomass concentration of 0.56 g/L and removing 76% TN, 72% TP, 93.1% COD, 93.5% Zn, and 82.5% Cu. The biomass contained 43.89% protein, 9.4% crude lipid, and other nutrients.
population_specificity: Spirulina platensis cultured in piggery wastewater.
effective_dosage: 4-fold dilution of piggery wastewater, 7 g/L sodium bicarbonate, pH 10.5, initial OD560 of 0.63, light intensity 3030 lx, light/dark cycle 16h/8h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Spirulina platensis alone and in combination with a native probiotic as an alternative to antibiotics in broiler chickens.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation improved intestinal morphology (villi height, villi length to crypt depth ratio, and villi surface) and microbial balance (higher Lactobacillus and lower E. coli counts). The combination of Spirulina and probiotic showed the best results, suggesting it as a viable alternative to antibiotics.
population_specificity: Male broiler chicks (336 birds, divided into 7 treatment groups).
effective_dosage: 0.2 g/kg Spirulina alone; 0.3 g/kg Spirulina combined with 0.5 g/kg native probiotic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Spirulina platensis extract on mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) proliferation, as well as its antioxidant and antimicrobial properties.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina platensis extract significantly increased MSC proliferation at 0.9 μl/ml concentration, demonstrated antioxidant activity (57% free radical scavenging), and showed antimicrobial effects (inhibition zones up to 11 mm).
population_specificity: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze previous studies on Spirulina's potential antibacterial activity, particularly against carbapenem-resistant bacteria like Klebsiella pneumoniae and Acinetobacter baumannii.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Spirulina may have antimicrobial activity, but no specific results or conclusive evidence are provided. The focus is on reviewing prior studies rather than presenting new findings.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of previous studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anticancer photodynamic therapy (PDT) efficacy of cubic spirulina platensis (CSP), microhelical spirulina platensis (MSP), and phycocyanin (Pc) against tongue cancer and fibroblast cells.
results_summary: All three photosensitizers were non-toxic to normal cells before laser irradiation. CSP and MSP were safe and efficient for anticancer-PDT, with CSP inducing apoptotic death and MSP mainly causing necrotic death, while Pc showed phototoxicity in higher concentrations.
population_specificity: CAL-27 (tongue cancer cell-line) and HGF (fibroblast cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a 6 g/day Spirulina supplementation for 14 days in improving cardiorespiratory parameters and hemoglobin levels during maximal and submaximal cycling in recreationally active individuals.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina supplementation increased hemoglobin concentration and improved various cardiorespiratory and lactate-based performance parameters during exercise.
population_specificity: 17 recreationally active individuals (14 male, 3 female, age 23 ± 5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina platensis could minimize rebound dyspepsia and reflux symptoms after proton pump inhibitor (PPI) discontinuation due to its anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties.
results_summary: Spirulina reduced rebound dyspepsia (55.56% vs. 88% in placebo) but did not significantly affect reflux symptoms. No significant side effects were reported in either group.
population_specificity: 45 Brazilian patients regularly using PPIs, excluding those with large hiatal hernias, peptic ulcers, or severe reflux esophagitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional and pharmacological benefits of Spirulina, including its biological aspects, patents, and potential future applications.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina is rich in essential nutrients and exhibits pharmacological effects such as antibacterial, anticancer, immune-stimulating, and antioxidant properties. It also modulates immunological activities and has anti-inflammatory qualities.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Spirulina supplementation on athletes, focusing on nutritional status, body composition, physical performance, and exercise-related disorders.
results_summary: Spirulina showed positive effects on body composition in overweight/obese subjects, improved aerobic fitness in untrained/moderately trained individuals, and enhanced antioxidant status and recovery from exercise-induced damage. Effects on strength and power were noted, though less significant in highly trained athletes.
population_specificity: Athletes, untrained, moderately trained, and highly trained subjects, as well as overweight/obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Spirulina platensis as an add-on therapy to metformin in improving glycemic control and lipid profiles in patients with uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced HbA1c, fasting blood sugar, triglycerides, total cholesterol, and LDL-C while marginally increasing HDL-C, demonstrating superior efficacy compared to metformin alone with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of spirulina supplementation on immune cell indicators in young soccer players during an 8-week tournament preparation period.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly altered basophil ratios and inhibited reductions in leukocytes and monocytes observed in the placebo group, suggesting potential immune-modulating effects against infections and allergies.
population_specificity: 39 undergraduate male soccer players.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify the study's goal regarding Spirulina.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings related to Spirulina.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on HIV and HAART).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Spirulina supplementation on pathological conditions, focusing on its antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The review found generally positive effects of Spirulina supplementation for various conditions, except male infertility, though the number of high-quality clinical trials was limited.
population_specificity: Subjects with both transmittable and non-transmittable diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of spirulina supplementation on pro/antioxidant status, inflammation, and skeletal muscle damage markers in elite rugby players after exhaustive exercise.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation prevented increases in lipid peroxidation (F2-Isop), inflammation (CRP), and skeletal muscle damage (CK) markers post-exercise compared to placebo. It also accelerated the return of these markers to baseline levels by 24 hours.
population_specificity: Seventeen elite male Rugby Union players.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential health benefits of Oxy+ (arthrospira/Spirulina) as a dietary supplement for managing various ailments.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that Spirulina contains bioactive compounds with antioxidant, immunomodulatory, and various protective effects, suggesting potential benefits for conditions like diabetes, hypertension, cancer, and autoimmune disorders. However, specific clinical outcomes or statistical results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dietary supplement use implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Spirulina supplementation on biomarkers of glycemic control and glucose metabolism in both human and animal subjects.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, total cholesterol, and triglycerides while increasing HDL-C in humans, but had no significant effect on HbA1C or LDL-C. In diabetic animals, it significantly reduced both fasting blood sugar and HbA1C.
population_specificity: Human subjects with diabetes or insulin resistance and diabetic animals (rats and mice).
effective_dosage: Less than 2 grams per day showed significant improvement in reducing fasting blood sugar in humans.
study_duration: Intervention duration less than 2 months was effective in humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Spirulina's efficacy in improving growth and anemia in underprivileged preschool children in Cambodia at the standard dose provided by institutions.
results_summary: Spirulina showed a modest trend toward improved weight gain (though not statistically significant) and significantly reduced anemia compared to placebo. Height gain was similar in both groups.
population_specificity: Preschool children cared for by a not-for-profit institution in Cambodia.
effective_dosage: 2 g per day (100 g total over the study period).
study_duration: 5 weeks per phase (with a wash-out period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of spirulina supplementation on antioxidant status biomarkers, focusing on total antioxidant capacity (TAC), superoxide dismutase (SOD), and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation showed marginal significant effects on TAC and SOD activity but did not affect GPx activity. The findings suggest potential benefits for enhancing the antioxidant system, though the effects were modest and not uniformly significant.
population_specificity: 415 subjects (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of spirulina supplementation on anthropometric indices, blood pressure, sleep quality, mood, fatigue status, and quality of life in ulcerative colitis patients.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced sleep disturbances and stress scores while improving quality of life, but did not significantly affect sleep quality, anxiety, depression, fatigue, anthropometric indices, or blood pressure compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Ulcerative colitis patients (n=80, with 73 completing the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spirulina supplementation improves redox status, muscle performance, and recovery after muscle-damaging exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefits of spirulina supplementation on redox status, muscle performance, or damage recovery compared to placebo following eccentric exercise. Both groups showed similar increases in muscle soreness and decreases in peak torque post-exercise.
population_specificity: 24 healthy, recreationally trained males
study_duration: Not specified (intervention duration not mentioned in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of spirulina supplementation during gradual weight loss on serum markers and body composition in competitive wrestlers.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation led to greater reductions in body fat percentage and fat mass compared to placebo, while also decreasing myostatin and liver enzyme concentrations. It maintained IGF-1 and follistatin levels, unlike the placebo group.
population_specificity: Competitive wrestlers (age 22 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: Two tablets of spirulina before each meal (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of spirulina supplementation on hemoglobin levels and physiological responses (oxygen uptake, RER, HR) during seated arm cycling exercise.
results_summary: Spirulina significantly increased hemoglobin levels, reduced oxygen uptake and heart rate during submaximal exercise, and improved oxygen uptake at fatigue, though time to fatigue remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Eleven untrained males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of spirulina in reducing obesity indices through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation showed significant ameliorative effects on weight, with a weighted mean difference of -1.85 kg (95% CI: -2.44, -1.26; p < .001). The meta-analysis supports its potential role in weight reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity or overweight (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects, mechanisms, and purification methods of bioactive peptides derived from Arthrospira sp. (Spirulina), focusing on antihypertensive, antimicrobial, and anticancer properties.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina-derived peptides exhibit significant therapeutic effects, including ACE inhibition for hypertension, antimicrobial activity against pathogens, and anticancer properties via apoptosis or angiogenesis inhibition. However, secondary effects were noted.
population_specificity: Not specified (review paper).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional benefits and toxic effects of selected seaweeds, including Spirulina, from red, brown, and green groups.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Spirulina's effects but highlights the need to address potential toxicity from chemical compounds, epiphytic bacteria, harmful algal blooms, and absorbed heavy metals in seaweeds.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the nutritional benefits of Spirulina, particularly its high vitamin B content.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that Spirulina is promoted for its high vitamin B content but does not provide specific study results on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of spirulina on glycemic control and serum lipoproteins in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders.
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis but did not provide specific results in the abstract. It assessed methodological quality and heterogeneity among included trials.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Spirulina supplementation on obesity-related anthropometric indices through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced body weight, particularly in obese individuals, and also decreased body fat percentage and waist circumference, but had no significant effect on body mass index or waist-to-hip ratio.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese participants from randomized clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of spirulina supplementation on oxidative stress indicators and inflammatory markers through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in interleukin-2 (IL-2) concentrations, though this became insignificant upon sensitivity analysis. Marginal decreases were observed in interleukin-6 (IL-6) and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS), particularly in participants with a baseline BMI below 25 kg/m².
population_specificity: 465 subjects across 11 studies (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the independent/synergistic effects of Spirulina in weight-loss interventions.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Spirulina's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Spirulina supplementation on metabolic syndrome components, liver manifestations, and related inflammatory markers.
results_summary: The systematic review found that Spirulina supplementation (1-19g/day for 0.5-6 months) had positive effects on metabolic syndrome components, suggesting it may be safe and effective, though optimal dosage and duration require further investigation.
population_specificity: Human models with factors associated with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if locally producible spirulina supplementation could improve infant physical growth, reduce morbidity, and enhance motor development in Zambian infants.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation did not significantly improve physical growth but reduced the likelihood of cough by 11 percentage points and improved motor milestone acquisition (walking alone at 15 months) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 501 Zambian infants (251 in the spirulina group, 250 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Spirulina 500 mg in reducing burning sensation and lesion size in patients with oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: Spirulina 500 mg supplementation twice daily, combined with topical steroids, showed statistically significant improvements in OLP symptoms compared to steroids alone. The study concluded that Spirulina could be an effective adjunct therapy for OLP.
population_specificity: 60 subjects with histopathologically confirmed OLP and symptoms of burning sensation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina supplementation could provide cardiovascular and metabolic benefits in obese patients with well-treated hypertension.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced body mass, BMI, waist circumference, LDL-C, IL-6, and improved total antioxidant status and insulin sensitivity compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Obese subjects with treated hypertension (n=50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if spirulina supplementation could modulate immune system responses in rowers undergoing maximal physical exercise, particularly in preventing immune function deficits.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation prevented post-exercise increases in Treg count and post-recovery decreases in Tδγ cell count, unlike the placebo group. It also resulted in lower Treg/CTL values and prevented changes in the Treg/(NK + Tδγ + CTL) ratio, suggesting protective effects against immune function deterioration.
population_specificity: 19 members of the Polish Rowing Team

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Spirulina supplementation could improve resistance to mental and physical fatigue in men.
results_summary: A 3 g/day dose of Spirulina led to a statistically significant increase in exercise output and improved performance in mental fatigue tests within 4 hours of the first dose, with sustained effects after 8 weeks. Subjective surveys also reported reduced physical and mental fatigue.
population_specificity: Men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Spirulina platensis supplementation could delay HIV disease progression by improving immune response and nutritional status in ART-naïve HIV-1 patients.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly increased CD4 cell counts and reduced viral load after 6 months, improved hemoglobin levels, and decreased fasting blood glucose after 12 months compared to the control group.
population_specificity: ART-naïve HIV-1 infected participants (67.1% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Spirulina platensis supplementation versus local diet on lipid profile in HIV-infected antiretroviral-naive patients.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly increased HDL-cholesterol and decreased total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, and triglycerides. The atherogenic index also improved significantly in the Spirulina group.
population_specificity: HIV-infected antiretroviral-naive patients (majority female, average age 35.6±9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 5 g/day Spirulina supplementation on immunological, virological, and antioxidant markers in HIV-infected women before HAART initiation.
results_summary: Spirulina significantly improved antioxidant capacity compared to placebo but showed no differences in immunological or virological markers. A slight increase in serum creatinine was observed in the Spirulina group, while fewer concomitant events occurred compared to placebo.
population_specificity: HIV-infected adult women not yet on HAART (n=73).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on the sources, production, extraction, and purification of C-phycocyanin (C-PC) from Spirulina, along with its potential industrial applications.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the commercial value of algal pigments like C-PC as natural colorants in nutraceutical, cosmetic, and pharmaceutical industries, driven by increasing consumer preference for natural products over synthetic compounds. It emphasizes techniques for C-PC extraction and purification but does not report specific health or efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Spirulina supplementation on plasma lipid concentrations through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL-C, and triglycerides while increasing HDL-C. The effects were independent of dosage but showed associations with the duration of supplementation.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of RCTs, but exact populations not detailed in abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (effects were independent of administered dose).
study_duration: Not specified (duration varied across included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of nanotechnology to obtain bioactive compounds coated with biopolymer nanocapsules from Spirulina biomass, focusing on its safety and potential applications in human and animal supplementation.
results_summary: The study highlights that Spirulina-derived biopolymers are biodegradable and suitable for nanoencapsulation, enhancing the bioavailability and stability of bioactive compounds. Spirulina is GRAS-certified, indicating its safety for human and animal use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human and animal supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Spirulina supplementation could reduce morbidity and mortality in HIV-infected adults and children.
results_summary: The study found that Spirulina supplementation did not significantly alter the risk of death, clinical outcomes, anthropometric measures, or immunological markers compared to placebo in HIV-infected individuals.
population_specificity: Malnourished, ART-naive HIV-positive adults and HIV-positive children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the lipid-lowering effects of Spirulina in dyslipidaemic Cretan Greek patients and assess its potential as an alternative treatment for dyslipidaemia.
results_summary: Spirulina supplementation significantly reduced triglycerides, LDL-cholesterol, total cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, and the total cholesterol to HDL-cholesterol ratio, while HDL-cholesterol levels showed a non-significant increase. Blood pressure, weight, and BMI remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 52 adult Cretan outpatients (32 men, 20 women) with recently diagnosed dyslipidaemia, median age 47 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Spirulina platensis versus soybean as a nutritional supplement on improving insulin sensitivity in HIV-infected patients with insulin resistance.
results_summary: Spirulina significantly improved insulin sensitivity by 224.7% compared to 60% with soybean, with 100% of spirulina-treated subjects showing improvement versus 69% in the soybean group. The study suggests spirulina is more effective than soybean for enhancing insulin sensitivity in this population.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients with insulin resistance receiving HAART in Cameroon.
